text.title: Create and Deploy a Java Web App to Google App Engine
text.head: Create and Deploy a Java Web App to Google App Engine
text.p: The Google App Engine is a Platform as a Service by Google. With App Engine, there are no servers for you to maintain. You simply upload your application and itâ€™s ready to go. This article is for anyone who knows a little bit of web development and want to create a web application which is live and accessible to all. This tutorial uses Java Plugin of Google App Engine and Eclipse IDE.
text.head: Steps
Setting up the Environment
text.p: This procedure installs the Google Plugin for Eclipse and optionally the Android Developer Tools, the Google Web Toolkit SDK, and the Google App Engine SDK.

list.item: Start Eclipse, running JVM version 1.7.0 or later.
Select Help > Install New Software.
In the dialog that appears, enter the update site URL into the Work with text box: "https://dl.google.com/eclipse/plugin/4.3". Press the key.
Select the checkbox next to Google Plugin for Eclipse (required). Click .
Review the features that you are about to install. Click .
Read the license agreements and then select "I accept the terms of the license agreements". Click .
Click on the Security Warning.
Click Restart Now to restart Eclipse.

Sign in to Google by clicking in bottom-right corner.
Provide the Google Account Credentials and Click .
Click â€˜Acceptâ€™ after reading the required permissions.
Now you are logged in to your Google Account.
You are ready to build App Engine web applications and mobile backends for your Android applications!

text.head: Creating the Application in GAE

list.item: Go to appengine.google.com
Login to your account using google account credentials .A new page is opened where it displays all the google app engine applications created by you.
Click â€˜Google Developers Consoleâ€™ link. A new window opens.
Google Developers Console is opened.
Click â€˜Create new Projectâ€™.
Enter the project name and edit the app ID as desired but it must be unique. An error is shown if the app id is not available.
Click . Your newly created app is ready. Now you can deploy the java web app code to this app id.

text.head: Creating the Application in Eclipse

list.item: Open Eclipse. Go to File > New > Web Application Project.
Enter the project name and package name. Uncheck the Google Web Toolkit.

Click .
Your project folder and its internal hierarchy will be created as shown in the figure.
Open index.html which is present in the war folder of your project.
Edit the HTML as desired. Currently we are not using any servlet hence remove the servlet link from the html.
Open web.xml and make sure that index.html is set as the welcome file.
Save the project.
